{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3393100,"name":"Gal","username":"GalDotan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T05:49:14.745Z","cooked":"

Currently in the market for Rock5A for vision processing, in the specs it mentions USB Typeâ€‘Câ„¢ PD Version 2.0 with 12V 2A input. Does this mean I can just plug it into the PDH? how do you power your co-processor?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-05-29T05:49:14.745Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":103.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466999,"topic_slug":"powering-rock5a-on-a-robot","display_username":"Gal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60986,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5951 Software and electrical lead"},"post_url":"/t/powering-rock5a-on-a-robot/466999/1","custom_user_title":"5951 Software and electrical lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3393102,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-29T06:00:07.215Z","cooked":"

No. Donâ€™t do that. Never power a coprocessor directly unless it have built in regulator (like limelight) as battery volt could drop to as low as 7V when the motor is running under load.

You could get an off the shelf USB PD charger for automotive as a voltage regulator. Something that look like these one.

These should be widely available on Amazon.

image1600Ã—1600 124 KB

Just make sure the charger do support PD over 30 Watt as recommended by the the wiki.

Where do you see that it needs 12V?

You can power it with a 5V USB supply just fine.

Using a USB-PD adapter meant for cars as mentioned is probably a good option too.

The only problem with these is that often the cutoff voltage is a bit too high for FRC usage. Being designed for automotive mainly, the need to have cutoff past ~8v isnâ€™t really there. Just make sure if you go with this solution, to pay attention to its input specifications. Preferred device cutoff voltage is around 5-6v.
